course_title: One Health: Diseases at the Human-Animal interface

learning_outcomes.description: Describe the bio-social context of a zoonotic disease to identify factors associated with the development and occurrence of zoonotic diseases.
Identify the roles, responsibilities and needs of key stakeholders associated with complex zoonotic disease problems.
Apply the principles of systems thinking to understand and analyse the structure and behaviour of complex zoonotic disease systems and identify feasible solutions.
Demonstrate effective communication (oral and written), collaborative teamwork and reflection skills.  .

assessments.due_date:
5/12/2025 2:00 pm

The last day of the intensive teaching block
assessments.task_description:
Students are required to analyse a specific One Health scenario and produce a presentation at the end of the week that includes a systems model to analyse the situation and describe intervention/leverage points with a multisectoral response action plan.

See the Task Sheet on the course Learn.UQ site for further detail.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Groups will submit their presentation slides via the submission link on the Learn.UQ site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date: Submission of FINAL One Health article critique 12/12/2025 2:00 pm
assessments.task_description:
1. Students will complete a structured critique of an article that describes a One Health problem and its resolution using the instructions and template provided on the course Learn.UQ site. Work to complete the assessment task will begin during the intensive teaching period.


The assessment mark is based on the mark given for the submitted template, which includes a self-assessment and a copy of notes from in-class discussions with peers and course staff.

See the Task Sheet on the course Learn.UQ site for further detail.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The One Health Article Critique must be submitted using the Turnitin link provided on the course Learn.UQ site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
12/01/2026 - 14/01/2026

Oral examinations will be scheduled between 9am and 4.30pm on each of the days in this period. Students will be able to choose from a series of times on a first come first serve basis. In-person examination is preferred.
assessments.task_description:
Each student will participate in an oral examination that comprises an initial three (3) questions aligned with Learning Outcomes 1-3 and three (3) additional critical inquiry questions. Each question must respond to a single One health problem chosen by the student from a list provided in the assessment task sheet. The One Health problems and initial 3 questions are provided in the assessment task sheet at the start of the course. The additional questions will not be disclosed prior to the examination. No course notes or pre-prepared materials may be used during the oral examination. 

The oral examination will comprise 6 questions - 3 of which are provided, 3 are not provided.

Further information and examination questions will be provided on the course Learn.UQ site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.
